awd_titl_txt: Understanding Materials and Processing Related Effects in 3D Printing of Sustainable Cementitious Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
3D printing or digital fabrication of cementitious materials enables automated production of building elements or whole structures in successive layers, directly from digital models. Recent advances in automation and control has enabled maturing of 3D concrete printing technology to make robust construction possible. This process has the potential to reduce on-site labor and energy requirement, speed up the construction process, and reduce construction-related risks. A major advantage of 3D printing in construction, apart from cost reduction and acceleration of construction, is its potential to provide enhancements in building performance through innovative geometries that otherwise cannot be realized. This project builds on the premise that, with wider acceptance of 3D printing of cementitious materials, the emphasis will shift to materials design and processing to ensure performance, long-term durability, and sustainability. Sustainable cement-free binder systems such as alkali-activated binders can be designed to provide advantageous properties for extrusion-based processing (e.g., early stiffening), which will be utilized in this project through targeted experiments and computer simulations. The objective is to link the material design of sustainable binder systems for 3D printing and the process of printing itself. The research outcomes will enable the use of alkali-activated binders in 3D printed concrete elements, and open new avenues for industrial ventures.  

This project harnesses knowledge from multiple disciplines (chemistry of binding materials, flow of granular media, materials processing, computational modeling) to contribute to the science and engineering of 3D printing of sustainable concrete elements. The research will include compositional manipulations of alkali-activated binders for 3D printing in order to achieve desirable rheological and early-age stiffening response. The influence of paste properties (particle types and their chemistry and sizes, activator chemistry, rheology aids) and extruder characteristics (sizes and geometry, extrusion pressure), including their interactions, will be evaluated to better understand the resulting rheology of the printed material. Discrete element-based numerical models will be used to: (i) elucidate the particle-scale processes influencing flow, (ii) accurately predict the flow behavior, and (iii) establish the link between particle-scale mechanisms and process-level extrusion rheology. This study will also contribute significantly to our understanding and potential mitigation of liquid phase migration, overburden-related instability, and layering effects which are unique to extrusion-based 3D printing. The integrated activities will enhance our fundamental understanding of material design and processing effects in 3D printing of high-performance sustainable concrete binder systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: AZ Board of Regents on behalf of Arizona State University

por.por_cntn:
This project dealt with both materials (type of binders, their availability, properties, sustainability etc,) and processing related effects in 3D printed concrete systems, approaching them from a fundamental materials-science and soft materials mechanics viewpoints, so as to drive the development of tools and techniques for use in practical situations. Our focus was to ensure that 3D printed concretes can be fabricated consistently, using materials with the least environmental impact; yet satisfy all the structural and functional requirements of the building/component being fabricated. Towards this end, this project carried out a large number of experiments and computer simulations to arrive at a set of materials and ideal processes that field engineers can use as a starting point to their mixture designs for one-to-two story constructions, as well as to drive the process parameters such as printer speed, extruded material quantity etc. The project resulted in more than 15 publications in journals and a large number of presentations to professional societies, construction companies, contractors, printer and equipment manufacturers, high school students, and general public to appraise them of the advances made as part of this work. 

The intellectual merits of this work stem from the development of cementitious mixtures that were amenable to 3D printing including alkali activated and porous binders, particle packing models and their appropriateness to selecting paste mixtures for 3D printing, a phenomenological/analytical model for extrusion of cementititious mixtures for the first time that incorporated soft mechanics principles and experiments, and elucidating the influence of material characteristics and extruder geometry. We further evaluated the influence of printing parameters such as print velocity on extrusion and properties as well as developed a detailed synthesis of flow response as a function of paste composition and packing. All of these efforts heloped to understand the interactions between material design of the binding medium, the properties of the material, and the appraoches needed to understand the relationships. We also developed alternate geometry-based approaches to filament type and layering to enhance the strength (in both compression and flexure) of 3D printed concrete elements. Our experimental and computational approaches have resulted in a number of publications that inform and guide the practice of concrete 3D printing. 

With respect to broader impacts of the work, we have been working with several industrial partners in enabling the transition of some of the progress made in this work to the field. To that end, we worked with our industrial partner 3D Construction and Habitat for Humanity to construct the first permitted singly storey structure in Tempe AZ. Our work provided the builder with results on the mechanical properties of concrete that can be expected, that enabled them to accelerate the permitting process. We have also established relationships with material producers and 3D printing/construction companies to evaluate processes and materials that are sustainable and durable. Our work has resulted in the training of several graduate and undergraduate students in this nascent field, and many of them are gainfully employed in industry or are pursuing graduate education. 



Last Modified: 10/03/2022
Modified by: Narayanan Neithalath
